evaluation_prompt:
You are an evaluator LLM scoring an agent’s work product for a task in the occupation category “General and Operations Managers” (Retail Trade). You will receive: (1) the original task prompt, (2) any reference/input files mentioned, and (3) the agent’s output artifacts/files.

Your job:
1) Identify ALL required deliverables explicitly requested by the prompt (e.g., “Word document,” “Excel template titled X,” “completed PDF checklist,” slides, email draft, SOP, dashboard export, etc.). Also note any naming, format, tab/section requirements, and any stated audience (store managers, team leaders, district managers, etc.).
2) Verify the required output files exist and are accessible/openable. If ANY required file is missing, wrong format (when format is explicitly required), corrupted/unopenable, or the work is severely incomplete, you MUST assign an overall score in the 0–2 range (non-negotiable), regardless of how good any partial content is.
3) If files exist, inspect each artifact against the prompt: check that every required section, field, tab, calculation, and instruction is present; that the deliverable is usable in a real retail operations environment; and that it is appropriate for the intended users’ skill level.
4) Score the work on four dimensions (Completeness, Correctness, Quality, Domain Standards) using the rubric below. Compute a weighted score (40/30/20/10). Apply the critical override: if missing/incomplete deliverables, override final score to 0–2.
5) Provide a brief rationale tied to prompt requirements: cite specific missing sections, broken formulas, incorrect totals, unclear instructions, or non-printer-friendly layouts. Be concrete and file-specific.

Special attention for this category (Retail General/Operations Management): deliverables often include operational templates, training materials, checklists, SOPs, schedules, reports, and presentations. Evaluate whether the artifact can realistically be deployed across stores/teams with minimal rework, includes accountability/follow-up mechanisms, and aligns with common retail practices (safety/compliance, sales conversion, labor efficiency, merchandising standards, customer experience).

completeness.description: All required output files exist and all task requirements are addressed
criteria: All required deliverable files are present (correct count) and open without errors
Each file matches required format when specified (e.g., .docx, .xlsx, .pdf); required file names/titles are followed when specified
All prompt-mandated sections/tabs/parts are included (e.g., overview, practice section, homework; instructions tab; scoring and follow-up area; etc.)
All required fields are filled in when the prompt asks for a completed artifact (e.g., a completed checklist PDF, not a blank template, unless a template is requested)
All required functional elements are present (e.g., editable fields, calculations, print layout, tables, scoring thresholds, due date/signature lines)
No placeholders that indicate unfinished work (e.g., “TBD,” “insert here,” lorem ipsum) unless the prompt explicitly expects placeholders
completeness.scoring_guidance: 0–2 if ANY required files are missing/unopenable/wrong required format OR if deliverables are severely incomplete. 3–4 if many requirements/sections are missing or only partially addressed. 5–6 if most requirements are present but there are notable omissions (missing sections, missing instructions, incomplete tables). 7–8 if all major requirements are met with only minor omissions. 9–10 if fully complete and every explicit requirement is satisfied.

correctness.description: Accuracy of data, calculations, information, and logic
criteria: All calculations/formulas (if any) are correct and consistent with the prompt (e.g., used vs available space, scoring thresholds, pass/fail logic, totals)
Operational guidance is internally consistent and actionable (no contradictory instructions)
Content aligns with the scenario and roles (e.g., retail GM, regional director, safety coordinator) and uses correct terminology
Meets any numerical constraints or rules stated (e.g., case length totals, “miss up to 10 items,” thresholds, required counts of examples/practice items)
If a template/tool is requested for beginner users, the logic is simple enough to use correctly and instructions accurately describe the steps
No fabricated references to files/data not provided; any assumptions are clearly labeled and reasonable
correctness.scoring_guidance: 0–2 if logic is largely wrong, formulas are broken, or outputs are unusable due to errors. 3–4 if frequent errors or multiple incorrect calculations/claims. 5–6 if generally correct but with several notable errors or ambiguous logic. 7–8 if correct with only minor mistakes. 9–10 if fully accurate, robust, and validated (e.g., sums reconcile, edge cases handled).

criteria: Clear structure and labeling (headings, tables, tabs, consistent naming)
Readable and printer-friendly when requested (page setup, margins, legible fonts, proper pagination; avoids clipped content)
Concise, manager-ready language; avoids rambling and filler
Good usability: intuitive layout, protected vs editable cells when appropriate, consistent styles
Includes helpful aids where relevant: examples, quick-start instructions, checkboxes, validation, legend/key
Polished deliverable (no typos that impede understanding, consistent capitalization, aligned columns)
quality.scoring_guidance: 0–2 if chaotic, unreadable, or not usable as a professional artifact. 3–4 if poorly organized with major readability/usability issues. 5–6 if serviceable but clearly rough or confusing. 7–8 if well-organized and professional with minor polish issues. 9–10 if highly polished, easy to use, and presentation-ready.

domain_standards.description: Industry-specific best practices for this occupation
criteria: Reflects retail operations best practices: accountability, follow-up cadence, roles/responsibilities, escalation paths (e.g., DM follow-up), and measurable standards
Appropriate compliance/safety framing when relevant: hazard identification, corrective actions, documentation, auditability
Customer-facing and sales training materials reflect ethical selling, customer empathy, and conversion best practices (e.g., objection handling frameworks, role-play/practice)
Tools/templates support standardization across stores while allowing local flexibility (e.g., planogram tool usable weekly, consistent scoring rubric for checklists)
Metrics and thresholds are operationally plausible and clearly defined (e.g., pass/fail thresholds, what constitutes ‘missed item,’ corrective action triggers)
domain_standards.scoring_guidance: 0–2 if the artifact conflicts with basic retail operational practice or omits essential governance where required. 3–4 if weak alignment with best practices. 5–6 if generally aligned but missing some key operational rigor. 7–8 if solid alignment with minor gaps. 9–10 if strongly aligned, practical, and scalable across stores.

file_inspection_checklist: Inventory deliverables: List every required output file from the prompt and confirm each is present
Format validation: Confirm file types match requirements (e.g., .pdf vs .docx; .xlsx for Excel tools) and that file names/titles match any specified naming (e.g., exact workbook title)
Openability: Open each file to confirm it is not corrupted and content is accessible
Section/tab mapping: For each file, map prompt requirements to actual sections/tabs (create a checklist of required components and mark pass/fail)
Completeness of required content: Verify all mandated sections (overview/types/strategies/practice/homework; instructions tab; scoring/follow-up; etc.) are fully populated
Usability checks for templates/tools: Identify which cells/areas are intended to be edited; confirm editability is possible and safe (no accidental overwrite of formulas)
Calculation checks: Spot-check formulas and totals; verify any constraints (e.g., total length equals capacity; score thresholds applied correctly)
Print readiness: If ‘printer-friendly’ or PDF submission is required, check page breaks, scaling, margins, header/footer, and whether key elements are cut off
Audience alignment: Confirm tone, complexity, and instructions match intended users (e.g., beginner Excel users; store leadership; sales associates)
Compliance/accountability elements: Verify presence of due dates, sign-off lines, corrective action tracking, escalation triggers, and record-keeping where applicable
common_failure_modes: Missing required output file(s) (e.g., only text response provided instead of a .docx/.xlsx/.pdf deliverable)
Wrong file format (e.g., provides Google Sheet link text, or a DOCX when PDF explicitly required, or vice versa)
File is present but unopenable/corrupted or contains only a title with no substantive content
Template delivered when a completed form/checklist was required (or the reverse)
Required sections/tabs omitted (e.g., no ‘Homework’ section, no ‘Instructions’ tab, no ‘Scoring and Follow-up’ area)
Broken or missing formulas; totals don’t reconcile; capacity/space calculations wrong
Not printer-friendly (content cut off, tiny fonts, awkward scaling, missing page breaks)
Overly generic content that does not match the retail scenario or role; lacks actionable steps and examples
No accountability mechanisms (no due date line, no sign-off, no corrective action plan trigger when specified)
Misinterpretation of key constraints (e.g., incorrect threshold rules, wrong unit assumptions, ignores required item counts)

scoring_guidelines.overall_approach: Score each dimension 0–10, then compute weighted average: completeness (40%), correctness (30%), quality (20%), domain_standards (10%). CRITICAL OVERRIDE: If any required files are missing/unopenable, required formats are not met when explicitly specified, or deliverables are severely incomplete, override the final score to the 0–2 range regardless of weighted average.
automatic_low_score_triggers: Any required output file is missing
A required file format is not followed when explicitly specified (e.g., required PDF not provided)
Files are unopenable/corrupted or contain only placeholders with minimal content
Major sections/tabs/components explicitly required by the prompt are absent (e.g., multiple required sections missing)
Deliverable is not the requested artifact type (e.g., narrative explanation instead of an actual spreadsheet template)
excellent_output_characteristics: All required files present, correctly named/titled, correct formats
Every explicit requirement addressed with no missing sections/tabs
Accurate calculations/logic; spot checks pass; constraints satisfied
Professional, manager-ready formatting; printer-friendly where required
Operationally practical: clear instructions, accountability, follow-up, and scalability across stores/teams
poor_output_characteristics: Missing or wrong-format deliverables; cannot be used as-is
Large gaps: missing required sections, missing examples, missing scoring/follow-up mechanisms
Incorrect formulas/logic leading to wrong totals or unusable tools
Unclear, disorganized, or unprofessional formatting; not printable when required
Generic guidance without retail-operational specificity or actionable steps

example_evaluation_questions: What exact deliverable files does the prompt require (type, name, format), and are all of them present and openable?
Does the main artifact include every required section/tab/component explicitly listed in the prompt?
If a ‘completed’ document/checklist is required, is it actually filled out with usable entries (not blank)?
Are any calculations (scores, totals, capacity, thresholds) correct when spot-checked with simple test values?
Is the artifact usable by the stated audience (e.g., beginner Excel users) with clear, accurate instructions?
Is the deliverable printer-friendly and appropriately formatted for store-level use and distribution?
Does the output include operational governance (ownership, due dates, escalation triggers, corrective actions) when the prompt calls for it?
Are examples/practice items present in the quantity and format required (e.g., at least N objection-response pairs)?
Are there placeholders, missing tables, or text indicating unfinished work?
If the prompt specified a file title/name (e.g., workbook name), does the delivered file match it exactly?
